}} 'Chlordiazepoxide' US Patent 2893992 (), is a sedative/hypnotic
drug and benzodiazepine. It is marketed under the trade names 'Angirex',
'Elenium', 'Klopoxid', '[[Librax]]' (also contains clidinium bromide),
'Libritabs', 'Librium', 'Mesural', 'Multum', 'Novapam', 'Risolid', 'Silibrin',
'Sonimen' and 'Tropium'.

Chlordiazepoxide was the first benzodiazepine to be synthesised and the
discovery of chlordiazepoxide was by pure chance. Chlordiazepoxide
and other benzodiazepines were initially accepted with widespread public
approval but were followed with widespread public disapproval and
recommendations for more restrictive medical guidelines for its use.

Chlordiazepoxide has a medium to long half-life but its active metabolite has a
very long half-life. The drug has amnestic, anxiolytic, hypnotic and skeletal
muscle relaxant properties.
